column58: In listening to the audio files, what stood out about the speakers' way of talking? In other words, what gave you the impression that someone was or wasn't from your country?
column59: Please evaluate the following statement: "There is a difference between American English and Canadian English. "
column60: If you answered "yes" to the previous question, in your opinion, what would those differences be?

column6: Moscow, Russia; Ottawa, Canada; Montreal, Canada
column58: A bit of a drawl for suspected Americans. What I believe to be American female voices had a bit of a distinction in vowel shape, but I can't comment more specifically.
column60: As above.

column6: Hopewell, NJ, USA (15 years, 9 months); Khonkaen, Thailand (8 months)
column58: Literally except for one who pronounced his "o"s in a vaguely stereotypically Canadian way, they all sounded the same.
column60: The only thing I can think of is the "o" thing. Maybe there are differences, but there are also so many variations in "American English" that you can't clearly tell whether it's a Canadian person or just an American with a different accent.

column6: Montreal, Canada, 13 years / Ottawa, Canada, 7 years / Toronto, Canada, 1 year
column58: First accent, second cadence. Vocabulary was nearly identical in most cases.
column60: I don't think my answer qualifies as a yes.

column6: Toronto, Canada (18 years), Montreal, Canada (2.5 years), Taipei, Taiwan (6 months)
column58: Some of them spoke with a little bit of "twang" which didn't sound very Canadian.
column60: Some words seem to be pronounced differently, and there are different turns of phrases used by the different countries.

column6:
Pennington, NJ  USA 1996-2014
New Brunswick, NJ USA 2014-present
column58: The way they said their O's and the cadency. If it was more up and down, then I predicted Canadian.
column60: I think the main difference is the O. For example, an American would pronounce "about" as "uh-bowt" and a Canadian would pronounce it "ab-owwut" as though the u had a very subtle umlaut.

column6: Philadelphia, PA, USA, 2.5 yrs; Titusville, NJ, USA, ~10 yrs; Budapest, Hungary, ~6 months; East Falmouth, MA, USA, ~4 yrs; Raleigh, NC, USA, ~4 yrs
column58: I felt like accents that I kind of expected/could pick up on in vowels stood out the most. The only reference that stuck out was the one about baseball.
column60: I most tightly associate it with a difference in vowel pronunciation (specifically "o"s)

column6:
East Brunswick, US, 1996-2000
Titusville, US, 2000-2014
Philadelphia, US, 2014-now
column58: "ow" sounds; intonation (??)
column60: "ow" sounds; different intonations

column6: Nobleton - Canada - 18 years, Montreal - Canada - 3 years
column58: The way vowels were pronounced.
column60: The pronunciation and intonation of vowels.

column6: Montreal, Canada, 3 years; Ottawa, Canada, 12 years; Kingston, Canada, 4 years; Halifax, Canada, 2 years; Toronto, Canada, 3 years
column58: Whether I could detect some similarity to the Southern US accents (a lighter version), this was indicative the person was from the US. Otherwise, it was hard to tell.
column60: It is highly dependent on the region. Some regions are very easy to tell apart (Quebec vs. Texas). The generic American accent in some areas seems to have slight tinges of the Southern accent, which makes it noticeably different. In other cases, the accents are very difficult to tell apart.

column6:
Ottawa - 19 years
Montreal - 4 years
Toronto - 10 months
column58: Pronunciation of certain words was a strong give away.
column60: More regional variations in American English? Though it was honestly quite hard for me to tell the difference.

column6: Deerfield, IL - 14 yrs; Durham NC - 4 yrs;  Kailua HI - 4 yrs; Menlo Park CA - 2 yrs; Minneapolis MN - 4 yrs, Hopewell NJ - 20 yrs; Kobe Japan - 2 yrs, Yokohama Japan - 2 yrs, Osaka Japan - 2 yrs; Jakarta Indonesia - 2 yrs
column58: All sounded like pretty standard English to me.  Sometimes I heard some words pronounced differently that made me think they might be Canadian vs American
column60: Different pronunciations of some words and some words not commonly used in American English.  Degree of the accent and pronunciation probably depends on what part of Canada the person is from and level of education.

column6: boston, usa, 18 years // Austin, Texas, 4 years to current// nyc, a year// rutland, Vermont, 20 years so far // Montreal 1.5 years so far
column58: I think the fact that I've lived in places with individually unique dialects (Boston, Texas, New York, mtl, and I live with two francophones) makes this both more of a challenge and more easy... I think I find that Canadian accents are similar to those in the Midwest United States, and tend to up the ends of their sentences more often and use more nasally intonations. they also say 'a' differently.
column60: I think see previous question- and content wise I think it depends but I find Americans are more to the point (particularly in the northeast) and talk faster.

column6: Newark, USA, 2 years
column58: Accent
column60: Pronunciation

column6: Pennington, NJ (18 yr) - New Brunswick, NJ (4 yr) - Xi'an, China (11 mo) - Dalian, China (11 mo) - State College, PA (2 yr)
column58: elongated "ous" "ohs" , or more nasal "a" but that could also be midwestern/Ohio accent
column60: How vowels are pronounced

column6: Acton, Massachusetts, USA (18 years) ; Montreal, QC, Canada (2.5 school years)
column58: Vowel sounds (raised); cadence/spacing between words (whether or not words would be pushed together, making me try extra hard to understand without reflection); fillers ("um" v. "like" v. "uh")
column60: Despite dialects that are shared across borders, the standardized forms are probably differentiated by vowel raising and nasality of vowels. Also the speed of the speech seems different between the two.

column6: Brampton, Canada (25 years); Pickering, Canada (10 years); London, England (8 months)
column58: Cultural cues (grade 1 vs 1st grade), certain inflections of speech, accents.
column60: Accent variations

column6: New York, New York - 2 years, New Rochelle, New York - 16 years, Montreal, Quebec - 2 years 7 months
column58: What stood out to me would have to be the person's subtle accent, the speed of their words, and whether or they not they would use things that I will call "sentence fillers" where a person in the absence of words to say will say something like "uh" or "like." I've been around the US a lot and have met many people from Canada and the US can be very varied in speech patterns so unless the accent itself was very different or the words used really made me think of another country I mostly thought that the speaker could be from my home country of the US.
column60: The slight differences would be in heavily accented parts of Canada and would be in some vernacular that is used in everyday language that is not seen within the United States as a whole which I did not really find any stark differences within these voice recordings.

column6: Guelph, Montreal
column58: Pronunciation of "o" sounds - like in "out" or "mom"
column60: Depends on where the person is from. When I think of Canadian English I imagine a "softer" pronunciation of things. I picture Americans as drawing out certain sounds a little more (like certain vowels).

column6: None.
column58: Pronunciation of certain words ("out" for example) or the choice of words/terms that are usually different depending on which country the speaker's from (US "first grade" instead of Canadian "grade 1")
column60: Pronunciation and word choice.

column6: Philadelphia
column58: The pacing, the level of informal speech ("um," "like," etc), pronunciation of vowels
column60: Longer O sounds!!

column6: Titusville, NJ 18 years Montreal, QC 2 years
column58: I recognized some Canadian raising/pronunciation; I recognized some linguistic facets of various American dialects.
column60: It's difficult to say what an American accent is, particularly because there are so many different dialects. I put yes because Canadian raising is a characteristic difference between American English and Canadian English; however, I do know that there are marginal American dialects with Canadian raising, so I did not say definitely true.

column58: How the vowels sounded. The Americans had a few that were drawn out more or were slightly different.
column60: Idioms, but I didn't hear any that stood out. Someone said "summered in... " at the end of a clip, which I understood, but is rarely used in my Canadian experience.

column6: New York City, USA, all my life
column58: The word "out" which was repeated in some of the audio files (Canadians typically have a certain way of pronouncing this one word). Also, some of them had very distinct accents (as in the man who had more of a southern way of speaking). In addition, the timing of their activities (as in the woman who went  Christmas tree shopping very soon after Thanksgiving - she would of had to be American since Canadian Thanksgiving is too far ahead of the Christmas season).
column60: I would say in the pronunciation of certain words - like "house," "out," and "about."
